Spartacus.Action: Decides to march on Rome instead of taking the safer option of using pirate ships.
Catches Crixus stealing supplies and confronts him.
Sparring and fighting alongside fellow gladiators under difficult conditions, demonstrating camaraderie.
Responds to provocation from the traitor Meroe, maintaining composure without escalation.
Participates in events that place him in opposition to authority, reflecting distrust from others.
Fights Dobie expertly and holds ground against sudden attack; shows skill and confident combat ability.
Engages in provoking situations with traitorous individuals leading to gladiator conflict, showing tactical awareness and readiness.
Aborts followers to drink with no directed purpose for their protection and ignores the Solon’s lodge.
Commands followers to fight and stay loyal despite dangers; attempts strategic coordination among diverse groups.
Orders punishment (flogging) of a follower for disobedience or failure.
Prefers his fate rather than capitulating or compromising under pressure.
Rejects overtures from adversaries attempting to undermine or manipulate him.
Engages in desperate combat or fights to death when facing overwhelming odds.
Leads a rebellion capable of destroying nine Roman armies, demonstrating exceptional leadership and military skill.
Commands troops who fight like free men, exemplifying his ability to inspire and organize effectively.
Rushes to help a slave boy trapped under a rock despite the risk to himself.
Speaks softly to the boy, trying to comfort him and lessen his fear.
Fiercely retaliates against the guard who harms him while trying to save the boy.
Shoves a heavy rock off a boy pinned underneath despite physical weakness and risk.
Softly instructs the boy to hold still and stop screaming, showing composure under pressure.
Rushes the guard out of rage but is struck down by whip, suggesting recklessness in confrontation.
Bites the guard's heel to disable him in close combat, demonstrating resourcefulness and fighting skill under duress.
Bites down hard on guard's Achilles tendon, causing guard to fall and cry out in pain despite being beaten and barely conscious.
Suffers heavy beating, panting and barely conscious on the ground, unable to escape or resist further effectively.
Glares balefully at Batiatus and responds with derision born of hate when asked what he wants.
Responds plainly and sincerely with 'Freedom!' showing straightforwardness.
Hamstrung a guard with his teeth not more than an hour ago, demonstrating practical combat skill and resourcefulness.
Slowly opens his eyes and glares balefully at Batiatus with jaw muscles knotted, showing controlled resistance and strong will rather than impulsiveness.
Responds to Batiatus' offer of anything he wants with a single word 'Freedom!' expressed with derision and hate, showing clear understanding of his goals and unwavering focus.
Almost spits out the word 'Freedom!' in response to a question, suggesting strong emotion but potentially risking negative perception.
Keeps pace and continues the grueling forced march despite exhaustion, demonstrating physical endurance and resilience under harsh conditions.
No direct action or statement shown in this excerpt.
Adapts to harsh new environment calmly without resistance, showing composure among fearful newcomers.
Remains observant and attentive to the training and harsh conditions imposed by trainers and guards.
Remains silent and restrained when addressed by Marcellus and others; does not show hostility despite being a slave and threatened.
Maintains composure and silently accepts being unchained by Marcellus despite being a condemned slave, showing controlled demeanor.
Accepts the sword from the guard, hesitates but fights Marcellus with skill and determination despite severe punishment.
Allows Crixus to help him to his feet without resistance or complaint.
Hesitates before attacking, then fights with viciousness and skill showing his trained gladiator abilities.
Despite skillful fighting, becomes exhausted, stunned, and is ultimately defeated and sprawls at Marcellus’ feet.
Asks David his name and how long he has been there, initiating friendly conversation.
Approaches Draba and tries to engage by asking where she is from and how long she has been there.
Shrugs off Draba's hostile rejection, stating he was just trying to be friendly.
Listens intently to warnings about Marcellus and potential danger.
Attempts to engage others by asking about their background and length of captivity.
Shrugs off Dreba's hostility and maintains a friendly approach despite rejection.
Just trying to be friendly (in response to being rejected by Draba).
States that gladiators make no friends and that he would have to kill if they ever met in the arena.
Attempts to be friendly despite the hostile environment.
Glares at visitors and sits tensely like a wild creature encountering a shocking figure for the first time.
Touches Varinia’s hair and cheek with exquisite delicacy and caution, showing respect and tenderness despite inner conflict.
Demonstrates fear, desire, wonder, eagerness, and shame in his approach to Varinia, reflecting sincerity and vulnerability.
Approaches Yarinia cautiously, with great delicacy and sensitivity, carefully touches her skin despite his intense emotions and uncertainty.
Is overwhelmed by Yarinia's beauty and presence, unable to comprehend or respond confidently, exhibiting hesitation and emotional conflict.
Admits to never having been with a woman, showing vulnerability and honesty.
Responds to the mockery and spying of his tormentors with hatred and defiance.
Threatens to kill his oppressors in a moment of desperation and anger.
Freezes and is dazed and unbelieving upon being overheard, showing vulnerability in a tense moment.
Leaps convulsively toward the bars and hangs by one hand, attempting to confront his tormentors aggressively.
Threatens to kill behind bars but is quickly subdued by Marcellus' boot, failing to overpower his captors.
Confesses his painful past and vulnerability to Varinia, admitting he has never had a woman in his life.
Turns away in shame and anguish after his confession, showing a moment of emotional openness and trust.
Allows Varinia to touch his shoulder in a gesture of sympathy, accepting comfort.
Thrown forcefully against a door attempting to lunge, showing physical aggression but lack of control or tactical finesse.
Is closely observed and trained by Marcellus in gladiator techniques, suggesting he is in a learning phase rather than demonstrating mastery.
Refuses to move despite physical provocation, holds glare of hatred on opponent's face.
Refuses to move despite Marcellus' taunts, keeps a glare of hatred fixed on him, showing controlled and confident defiance in a tense situation.
Does not verbally respond to Marcellus' provocation or explain his interest in Varinia, maintaining silence.
Stares off to Varinia, rigid with fury and humiliation, showing emotional vulnerability toward her.
Lunges at Marcellus after Varinia is taken away, reacting strongly to the mistreatment of someone he cares about.
Remains silent and rigid with fury and humiliation but does not respond aggressively or strategically to verbal taunts or physical provocations.
Lunges impulsively at Marcellus after being mocked, but is easily evaded and crashes into the cell door.
Successfully navigates the dangerous blade machine pattern by ducking and leaping through rapidly spinning blades without injury.
Seizes Varinia's hand-cart during jogging and drags it along playfully, then laughs as she gasps indignantly and runs after it.
Leaping and ducking with rigid concentration and sweat, demonstrating physical skill and focus during training.
Seizes Varinia's cart and drags it along while jogging, evading guards' notice and showing playful confidence and situational awareness.
Offers his hand to help Draba up after their duel.
Is knocked down by Draba's betrayal with a sword at his throat despite offering help.
Fends Draba's lunge, uses speed and intensity to turn Draba on his hip and send him sprawling.
Offers a hand to help Draba up after knocking him down, showing sportsmanship and confidence.
Is suddenly pulled down by Draba and caught off guard with a sword at his throat, showing a momentary lapse in vigilance.
Grins and playfully topples Draba back into the water from behind.
Casts a furious glance at Draba and leaves after being told to get off the field.
Rises after sword is withdrawn, casts a furious glance at Draba, and leaves the field with confidence.
Playfully topples Draba into the water with a quick move, showing physical agility and confidence.
Does not escalate confrontation despite provocation, showing emotional self-control and strategic restraint.
Grins and playfully topples Draba into the pool from behind
Asks David sincerely about his prayer shawl and his past as a rabbi
Frowns thoughtfully while considering David's explanation of his faith
Grins and playfully topples Draba into the water, showing confidence and physical agility.
Engages in conversation with David about the prayer shawl and the role of a rabbi, demonstrating curiosity and thoughtful consideration.
Questions the efficacy of the 'true god' in freeing prisoners, showing critical thinking and skepticism.
Pauses to consider the religious explanation, indicating reflective thought rather than impulsiveness.
Shows respectful greetings to various nobles and hosts the event with apparent sincerity and honor toward his guests.
Referencing the practice of gladiators fighting to the death once sold but stressing that while at the training site they never fight to death, indicating a protective stance toward his trainees.
Responds calmly and philosophically to the announcement of a fight to the death, emphasizing the value of life to himself and others.
Responds calmly and philosophically to the announcement of a fight to the death, emphasizing the value of life.
Does not panic or show despair upon hearing about the deadly fight, maintaining composure.
Admits he would have to kill to survive in a fight, showing pragmatic acceptance of harsh realities.
After careful thought, admits he would kill to stay alive if forced to fight Crixus, showing realistic self-awareness and acceptance of harsh realities.
Responds confidently and deliberately when asked if he would fight and kill, indicating mental preparedness and clear decision-making.
Stares at the assembled guests as if they were the animals on display rather than himself, maintaining composure under dehumanizing conditions.
Does not react with fear or desperation while imprisoned and during the show, exhibiting a calm and thoughtful demeanor.
Lacks direct action or interaction in this excerpt, merely observing without apparent initiative or leadership.
Allows Helena to inspect him with insolent tolerance, showing no visible resentment.
Does not react aggressively or boastfully when called 'beast' or 'coward' during the tense inspection.
Maintains eye contact with Varinia when she approaches with wine, signaling openness or sincerity.
Stands confidently and silently under intense inspection by Helena, demonstrating control and presence.
Remains calm and non-reactive when others react strongly around him, showing self-possession and composure.
Does not verbally respond to provocations or condescending remarks, potentially missing opportunities to assert himself.
Moves silently to the arena-side wall and peers out through a crack to observe the fight cautiously.
Rises slowly and turns with a white face after whistle sounds, moving back toward the bench without showing active engagement.
Dodges a deadly thrust with a rolling spin and tries to recover quickly.
Gets caught in the net and thrashes ineffectively, failing to escape.
Panting, exhausted, utterly defeated, immobilized and waiting for death without fighting back.
Rises slowly from the sand at a moment when opponent is distracted and charging toward the stands.
Stares at the defiled body of a dead comrade with horror, indicating emotional awareness and recognition of the gravity of the situation.
Reacting with a convulsion of pure rage, he violently upsets a scalding cauldron, causing Marcellus to be buried beneath it.
Leads the gladiators and slaves in a coordinated revolt, efficiently overcoming guards using both physical prowess and strategy.
Ensures that unarmed fighters seize weapons from the arsenal, demonstrating foresight and tactical planning.
Does not hesitate to fight directly and overpower guards, showing confidence and skill in combat.
Leads the triumphant breakout of slaves and gladiators through the gates, capitalizing on the death of the guards and the destruction around them.
Does not appear explicitly in this excerpt taking direct actions or making decisions, limiting evidence of individual competence.
Replies positively to Dionysius' report with a focus on practical needs and care for followers.
Leads a company of horsemen through dangerous terrain, demonstrating command and tactical movement.
Receives report from Dionysius about the deserted countryside and abandoned equipment, then promptly orders search for wagons, horses, and supplies.
Organizes groups to raid countryside, liberates supplies and animals.
Directs leaders efficiently to gather wagons, horses, and supplies, showing organized leadership and planning.
Leads groups of horsemen to swiftly and energetically raid the countryside, demonstrating strategic initiative and execution.
Observes the logistical operation of loading loot carefully and thoughtfully, showing situational awareness and control.
Passes slowly and alone through the damaged school grounds, reflecting on the changed environment and his own transformation, indicating introspection but no immediate action.
Pauses and gazes at the arch where Draba's body was suspended, showing a moment of solemn reflection and respect.
Walks slowly and dreamily alone, appearing disconnected from others’ bustling activity, showing some emotional distance.
Sits quietly on the bench waiting, showing patience and calmness but no explicit social interaction.
Walks slowly and meditatively through the destroyed cell block, taking in the desolation and reflecting on changes.
Sits quietly in the ruined kitchen, absorbed in memories of Varinia; shows restraint and introspection despite surrounding desolation and jeering outside.
Rises slowly when hearing the men jeering and calling to violence, showing a puzzled but measured response rather than anger or aggression.
Exits silently after listening to the hostile crowd, choosing not to engage in or escalate the conflict.
Carefully observes his surroundings and listens attentively to subtle changes in external sounds, indicating awareness and caution.
Appears absorbed in memories and the past, which subdues his awareness of external activity initially.
Steps between two Romans about to fight and urges them to throw down their swords, condemning the violence and manipulation by their masters.
Expresses disgust and hatred toward Rome and Romans but struggles to control his emotions, showing his sincere internal conflict.
Reflects on the brutal spectacle and questions what they have truly gained, implying empathy and a desire for higher values beyond violence.
Steps into the arena to intervene and stop Romans from fighting each other, demonstrating leadership and strategic thinking to preserve his people.
Struggles to control his emotions due to hatred and personal feelings, impairing his ability to act purely rationally at the moment.
Commands the crowd to stop participating in Roman games and urges them to burn down the gladiatorial school instead, correctly perceiving the emotional state and motivations of his followers.
Clearly states his purpose is to save his people, not the Romans, demonstrating strategic clarity and confidence.
Helps newly escaped slaves to clamber aboard wagons while riding away from Capua.
Responds to escaping slaves' shouts and encourages them to follow.
Notices Varinia watching him, shows recognition and emotional pause before moving on.
Leads a large group of slaves successfully escaping and evacuating the burning gladiatorial school.
Commands his men to continue moving despite a momentary personal distraction upon recognizing Varinia.
Affirms Varina's freedom and insists nobody can force her to stay or go with anyone.
Expresses love and possessiveness by saying 'I do forbid you' when Varina tries to leave, showing both affection and control.
Holds Varina tightly with passionate but clumsy inexperience, unintentionally hurting her and quickly releasing her when she says he's hurting her.
Expresses love and tenderness despite inexperience, shows awareness by releasing Varinia when he hurts her.
Shows clumsy, bear-like passion lacking delicacy in love-making, unintentionally hurts Varinia.
Rides through the camp observing all activity and interacts with Crixus, showing interest in the well-being and progress of his men.
Introduces himself clearly and respectfully to the new escapees, showing openness to them.
Frowns and criticizes the presence of too many women among the new escapees.
Enters a group of new escapees confidently, identifies himself clearly as their leader.
Criticizes the new escapees for bringing too many women, potentially showing poor social awareness or tact.
Lifts the old crone gently as one does with a child, smiling and sharing a private amusement with her.
Establishes simple and fair rules including 'women belong to themselves,' showing respect and tolerance.
Assigns roles based on individual skills and treats people as capable and valuable.
Engages confidently and warmly with the old crone by lifting her playfully and making a humorous remark about needing shrouds, showing ease with people and morale-building.
Clearly states simple but effective rules for the group establishing order and respect, demonstrating leadership and organizational skill.

Assesses the skills of slaves, assigning roles based on their past experience (e.g., carpenters for construction tasks, steward for food supplies), showing practical intelligence and resource management.
Notices Antoninus's clothing and questions his work, trying to understand the group composition, reflecting observational and evaluative competence.
Encourages Antoninus to learn a useful and practical skill rather than only perform tricks; emphasizes the importance of becoming capable fighters.
Dismisses magic tricks and poetry as insufficient skills for their situation; focuses on practical combat training.
Smiles warmly and appreciates a small kindness (receiving an egg), showing interpersonal skill and patience.
Attempts to crack the egg awkwardly and ends up with a mess on his hands, then smiles despite embarrassment.
Attempts to crack an egg carefully but does so awkwardly, resulting in a mess and eliciting laughter and nervous tittering from others.
After the awkward failure, slowly regains composure and manages to smile at Antoninus, showing emotional resilience and some social confidence.
Inquires about Antoninus' songs with genuine interest and respect.
Decides Antoninus will teach songs rather than fighting, showing trust and appreciation for his talents.
Turns away simply to settle the matter without argument or hostility.
Recognizes that fighting is not always the answer and decides to have Antoninus teach songs instead, showing understanding of timing and strategy beyond mere combat.
Rises and stares intently, then makes a firm decision to shift the group's focus, demonstrating confident leadership and decisiveness.
Shares his insecurities openly with Varinia, admitting he is illiterate and unsure about his knowledge.
Engages in a sincere, tender conversation with Varinia about understanding and beauty.
Expresses self-doubt about his knowledge and skills, admits he cannot read.
Shows emotional insight and poetic sensibility when speaking about singing and understanding things beyond formal learning.
Demonstrates curiosity and desire to learn about the world and his surroundings.
Responds immediately to alert and rising panic at the encampment, getting up with others to face threat.
Touches Crizxus' arm gently, asks him to leave the terrified man alone, helps the man to rise despite the tense situation.
Lifts the frightened little girl into his arms, smiles warmly to comfort her.
Calmly intervenes to stop Crixus from beating a fearful man, showing leadership and restraint.
Gently but firmly helps the terrified man to his feet, managing a tense situation steadily.
Comforts a frightened child by holding her and smiling to calm her, showing emotional intelligence in crisis.
Bends down and sweeps frightened little girl into his arms, smiles gently at her, comforts her tenderly.
Draws child close to his shoulder and cuddles her while explaining comforting but honest message.
Hands child over lovingly to Varinia for care, showing responsibility and trust.
Calms and comforts a terrified young child by gently holding and speaking to her, showing emotional intelligence and leadership presence.
Addresses his followers confidently about the strategic situation, recognizing that Rome itself has come to them rather than needing to march on Rome.
Takes initiative to organize supplies and weapons after battle, showing practical skills in logistics and resource management.
Encourages the defeated Roman commander to raise his head and stop shaking, addresses him directly and calmly.
Grins at Antoninus but acknowledges he fought well despite circumstances.
Calmly confronts the captured Roman commander Glabrus, commanding attention and maintaining control of the situation.
Uses psychological tactics by forcing Glabrus to face the crowd and lowering his pride, undermining his authority.
Engages Antoninus with a grin and supportive words, showing emotional intelligence and leadership in encouraging allies.
Encourages Glabrus to stand up and face him without fear, speaks calmly and questions him respectfully.
Stops Crixus from killing Glabrus despite crowd's expectation and Crixus's fierce insistence.
Mocks Glabrus by suggesting stripping him down and fighting to see Roman blood, using sarcastic tone.
Calmly confronts the Roman commander Glabrus and commands him to stand with dignity, displaying control and psychological insight.
Proposes a fair fight between Crixus and Glabrus to settle matters, showing tactical thinking and leadership.
Stops Crixus from killing Glabrus impulsively, demonstrating restraint and strategic foresight.
Fingers the golden bracelet on Glabrus’ wrist, perhaps assessing his status, showing attentiveness and situational awareness.
Engages in banter with Glabrus and tests his courage in front of the crowd, using psychological tactics to assert dominance.
Breaks the symbol of Roman power and gives it back to the enemy with a message demanding freedom, then leads the crowd with determination and joy.
Breaks the ivory baton symbolizing Roman power and boldly challenges the Senate through a captured officer, demonstrating confident leadership and psychological insight.
Commands the crowd and effectively uses humor and theatricality to boost morale and mock the enemy, showing skillful manipulation of public sentiment.
Leads strategic discussions, recognizes key logistical challenges, and devises a clever plan involving Antoninus to secure ships and funds.
Acknowledges difficulties in army training and movement but insists on continuing forward despite obstacles.
Shows awareness of people's roles and uses others' skills (Antoninus's experience as a traveling entertainer) for practical advantage.
Throws stones with precision, hitting close to Varinia, showing controlled aim and playful skill.
Laughs out loud and moves quickly down the hill causing a small avalanche, showing physical agility and confidence.
Approaches Varinia steadily despite her protests, demonstrating confidence and assertiveness.
Shrugs off Varinia's refusal to come closer and continues his approach, which could be seen as ignoring social cues or boundaries.
Laughs and playfully lifts Varinia despite her protests.
Kisses Varinia even as she struggles and protests.
Carefully sets Varinia down after learning she is pregnant, showing awe and apologizing.
Teasingly advances on Varinia, picks her up despite her protests, and laughs while handling the situation confidently.
Is momentarily stunned and unable to speak or think upon learning Varinia is pregnant, shows hesitation and decreased decisiveness.
Carefully sets Varinia down once he understands her fragile condition, speaks apologetically and thoughtfully.
Apologizes gently and with concern to Varinia after causing her slight harm
Shows tenderness and care by carefully kissing Varinia and then sharing his poncho to protect them both
Initially kisses Varinia somewhat awkwardly and without passion, indicating slight emotional reserve
Shows care and tenderness toward Varinia, gently kisses her and carefully drapes his poncho over her to protect both of them.
Appears shaken and unsure when Varinia mentions possible harm to the baby, indicating emotional vulnerability.
Leads a victorious slave army with pennons flying, inspiring joy and hope among escaped slaves who run toward him waving and calling out his name.
Trying to get out of Italy to end the crisis, indicating strategic thinking and situational awareness.
His actions directly influence political power struggles in Rome, showing his significant impact and capability.
No direct actions or detailed plans are mentioned in this excerpt, causing some ambiguity about his immediate competence.
Attempts to get out of Italy to avoid a direct confrontation with Rome, showing strategic awareness.
Does not yet appear in direct action or decision within this excerpt, which limits evidence of his competence here.
Spartacus and leaders share the wild emotions of the moment with their men, observing thoughtfully and allowing the men to celebrate together down the hill.
Shows consideration and trust by coordinating and ordering communication with rear units to camp by the sea.
Observes the scene with thoughtful caution despite the moment of joy, showing awareness and restraint.
Confidently states control of the back country and anticipates strategic movements, demonstrating situational awareness and leadership.
Issues clear orders to communicate with all units to camp by the sea, showing command and organizational skill.
Orders the units to camp by the sea tonight, showing forward thinking and tactical planning.
Responds decisively to the dilemma of being trapped in Italy by stating there is only one thing they can do.
Fails to have ships or a means of naval escape, which limits options and shows lack of resources.
Speaks honestly to his followers about their difficult situation and the truth behind their potential victory.
Shows concern for Varinia and the unborn child, acknowledging the difficulties of travel during pregnancy.
Considers the strategic military situation accurately, proposes a decisive plan to defeat Crassus before Pompey arrives, showing understanding of timing and positioning.
Commands immediate action by ordering the march tonight, demonstrating decisiveness and leadership.
Encourages honesty with the troops about their situation, instilling confidence by reminding them of previous victories.
Shares a tender moment with Varinia, showing emotional awareness but slightly distracted from the battle focus.
Expresses doubt and guilt about leading others to a likely death.
Asks Varinia to tell the truth to their child, showing sincerity and trust.
Rejects Varinia's comforting embrace, fearing it will make him weak.
Acknowledges the overwhelming odds against them and contemplates the potential end of their struggle realistically.
Expresses deep self-doubt about the correctness of his decisions despite being the leader who gave orders.
Shows emotional vulnerability by needing comfort and then rejecting it to maintain strength.
Has won multiple battles against Roman forces, demonstrating talent in handling an army.
Wins with numbers, suggesting reliance on numerical advantage rather than superior skill according to Caesar.
Fought brilliantly against Draba, delivering a brilliant dagger stroke from a difficult angle.
Fails to be captured despite Crassus’s pursuit and despite being mocked for cowardice by a guard.
Is promised by Crassus to be delivered as a prisoner but is not, indicating ability to evade or resist capture.
Sits silently among prisoners, does not betray himself despite offer of freedom to anyone identifying him.
Others falsely claim to be Spartacus to protect him, showing his importance but he himself seems momentarily unable to fully grasp the impact of their actions.
Allows other prisoners to claim his identity to protect them, shows emotional vulnerability with tears of joy, and laughs warmly with them.
Gives Batiatus a terrible glare of warning and hatred when recognized, showing distrust and hostility.
No direct action or statement within this excerpt to evaluate warmth; largely focused on Crassus and Varinia interaction.
Inspired thousands to willingly risk their lives for him.
He began all alone like an animal but inspired thousands who would have died in his place.
Loved sincerely by Varinia, who calls him a simple man and expresses genuine love.
Portrayed by Crassus as an outlaw, murderer, and enemy, reflecting others' distrust.
Reacts with impotent fury and pain to the crucifixion of a crippled fellow slave.
Responds to Antoninus's observation of a nightbird with a calm, shared memory, acknowledging the presence of hope despite their dire situation.
Remains composed and engages in a quiet, almost intimate conversation with Antoninus despite being chained, filthy, exhausted, hungry, utterly defeated.
No visible attempt to escape or resist while chained and defeated; quietly endures suffering.
Admits to weeping over losses and his dead son when asked by Antoninus.
Expresses doubt about gods but holds on to hope for understanding tomorrow.
Shows despair about the world but shares his feelings openly with Antoninus.
Acknowledges the emotional weight of their loss and reflects thoughtfully on the impact of their rebellion, showing awareness and a considered perspective.
Expresses doubt about gods and the meaning of their struggle, showing inner conflict and uncertainty.
Affirms that simply resisting Rome causes fear and represents a meaningful victory, demonstrating strategic insight and confidence in their influence.
Does not respond directly to Antoninus’s question about winning or the gods, which may indicate hesitation or inability to provide firm answers in critical moments.
Refuses to betray despite the hopeless situation, showing steadfastness and leadership under pressure.
Remains silent or less noticed in the presence of Crassus who focuses more on Antoninus, indicating possible overshadowing or missed opportunity to assert himself.
Looks Crassus straight in the face and replies with a smile despite being slapped.
Mocks Crassus by laughing and spitting in his face.
Maintains silence and calm defiance under interrogation, looking Crassus straight in the face without fear.
Responds to Crassus's slap with a confident, mocking smile and pointed questions that highlight Crassus's failures.
Spits in Crassus's face boldly, asserting psychological dominance despite being physically unchained and vulnerable.
Reassures Antoninus by saying 'There's nothing to fear... It will come quickly... One swift thrust and it will be over.'
Expresses love to Antoninus, calling him like a son he will never see.
Kills Antoninus swiftly and mercifully to relieve his suffering.
Throws Antoninus over his hip and chops down at the base of his neck to incapacitate him during combat.
Maintains control and decisively kills Antoninus despite visible exhaustion and agony.
Expresses deep emotional pain and love for Antoninus but does not hesitate to kill him when necessary.
Carries the dead body of Antoninus tenderly in his arms as one would a child, showing deep reverence and sorrow.
Expresses horror and anguish upon learning that Varinia and her child live as slaves, indicating his empathy and caring nature.
Carries the dead body of Antoninus solemnly to Crassus and offers it to him, showing emotional strength and resolve despite horror and hatred.
Expresses a prophetic declaration that Antoninus will return 'and he'll be millions,' indicating insight and confident vision.
Momentarily stunned and silent after Crassus' revelation about Varinia and her child as slaves, showing a vulnerable emotional reaction.
Tries to understand Varinia's decision to leave with their child despite his agony and impending death.
Looks after Varinia and the child as they leave, showing concern even in his final moments.
Despite being gravely wounded and near death, shows awareness and understanding of Varinia's departure and the fate of his son.
Unable to communicate or physically respond due to his critical condition, rendering him passive in a crucial moment.
Struggles to communicate to Varinia that their son is free despite his own imminent death, manages a smile and utters the word 'Free' as an expression of victory and selflessness.
Utters the word 'Free' with a voice that thrills with victory despite being on the brink of death.
Unable to communicate fully with Varinia due to dying, despite wanting to share his understanding.
